metadata.title: Designing for iPadOS | Apple Developer Documentation
metadata.author: Apple Inc.
metadata.summary: Apple Developer Documentation page providing design guidelines for iPadOS applications. The document covers fundamental device characteristics, input methods, system features, and best practices for creating iPad experiences that integrate platform capabilities.
metadata.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

items.note: Additional items truncated in sidebar view

content.text: People value the power, mobility, and flexibility of iPad as they enjoy media, play games, perform detailed productivity tasks, and bring their creations to life.

content.description: A stylized illustration of an iPad device shown at a slight angle. The iPad is depicted as a rounded rectangle outline in dark teal/green color against a lighter mint green square background. The iPad screen area contains a simple line drawing icon representing a generic device or app interface. The illustration uses a minimalist, geometric style consistent with Apple's design language.
content.composition: Centered iPad illustration on a square background, device shown at slight perspective angle
content.technicalDetails: Vector illustration, appears to be SVG or high-resolution PNG
content.contextualRelevance: Hero image representing iPad platform for the design guidelines page
content.style: Apple's modern illustration style with rounded corners, subtle gradients, and clean geometric shapes

content.text: As you begin designing your app or game for iPad, start by understanding the following fundamental device characteristics and patterns that distinguish the iPadOS experience. Using these characteristics and patterns to inform your design decisions can help you provide an app or game that iPad users appreciate.
iPad has a large, high-resolution display.
content.fullText: Display. iPad has a large, high-resolution display.

content.text: People often hold their iPad while using it, but they might also set it on a surface or place it on a stand. Positioning the device in different ways can change the viewing distance, although people are typically within about 3 feet of the device as they interact with it.
content.fullText: Ergonomics. People often hold their iPad while using it, but they might also set it on a surface or place it on a stand. Positioning the device in different ways can change the viewing distance, although people are typically within about 3 feet of the device as they interact with it.

content.text: People can interact with iPad using Multi-Touch gestures and virtual keyboards, an attached keyboard or pointing device, Apple Pencil, or voice, and they often combine multiple input modes.
content.fullText: Inputs. People can interact with iPad using Multi-Touch gestures and virtual keyboards, an attached keyboard or pointing device, Apple Pencil, or voice, and they often combine multiple input modes.

content.text: Sometimes, people perform a few quick actions on their iPad. At other times, they spend hours immersed in games, media, content creation, or productivity tasks. People frequently have multiple apps open at the same time, and they appreciate viewing more than one app onscreen at once and taking advantage of inter-app capabilities like drag and drop.
content.fullText: App interactions. Sometimes, people perform a few quick actions on their iPad. At other times, they spend hours immersed in games, media, content creation, or productivity tasks. People frequently have multiple apps open at the same time, and they appreciate viewing more than one app onscreen at once and taking advantage of inter-app capabilities like drag and drop.

content.text: iPadOS provides several features that help people interact with the system and their apps in familiar, consistent ways.
content.fullText: System features. iPadOS provides several features that help people interact with the system and their apps in familiar, consistent ways.

content.text: Great iPad experiences integrate the platform and device capabilities that people value most. To help your experience feel at home in iPadOS, prioritize the following ways to incorporate these features and capabilities.

items.text: Take advantage of the large display to elevate the content people care about, minimizing modal interfaces and full-screen transitions, and positioning onscreen controls where they're easy to reach, but not in the way.
Use viewing distance and input mode to help you determine the size and density of the onscreen content you display.
Let people use Multi-Touch gestures, a physical keyboard or trackpad, or Apple Pencil, and consider supporting unique interactions that combine multiple input modes.

Adapt seamlessly to appearance changes — like device orientation, multitasking modes, Dark Mode, and Dynamic Type — and transition effortlessly to running in macOS, letting people choose the configurations that work best for them.

thumbnail.description: Dark background with Apple Pencil and colorful circular UI elements (red, yellow, teal dots) suggesting a creative/design interface. WWDC badge visible in corner.

cards.title: Elevate the design of your iPad app

thumbnail.description: Abstract liquid glass effect showing translucent, flowing glass-like material in soft blue and white tones. WWDC badge visible in corner.

Screenshot showing multiple iPad apps with the new design system, featuring translucent materials and layered interfaces. Shows what appears to be a photo gallery or media app. WWDC badge visible in corner.

cards.title: Get to know the new design system

bottomBar.feedbackText: To submit feedback on documentation, visit Feedback Assistant.
bottomBar.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

pages.pageSummary: This page provides Apple's official design guidelines for iPadOS applications. It introduces five key device characteristics (Display, Ergonomics, Inputs, App interactions, System features) and links to related system features (Multitasking, Widgets, Drag and drop). The Best practices section outlines four main recommendations for creating great iPad experiences. The Resources section provides links to Apple Design Resources, iPadOS Pathway documentation, and three WWDC videos about iPad app design and the new Liquid Glass design system.

crossPageElements.runningFooters: Apple Developer footer with site navigation

sections.title: Introduction

subsections.title: Display
subsections.summary: iPad features a large, high-resolution display.

subsections.title: Ergonomics
subsections.summary: Users hold iPad or place it on surfaces/stands, typically viewing from within 3 feet.

subsections.title: Inputs
subsections.summary: Multiple input methods: Multi-Touch, keyboards, pointing devices, Apple Pencil, and voice.

subsections.title: App interactions
subsections.summary: Users perform quick actions or extended sessions, often using multiple apps simultaneously.

subsections.title: System features
subsections.summary: iPadOS provides Multitasking, Widgets, and Drag and drop capabilities.

sections.summary: Overview of fundamental iPad device characteristics and usage patterns that distinguish the iPadOS experience.

sections.title: Best practices
sections.summary: Four key recommendations for creating great iPad experiences: leverage large display, consider viewing distance and input mode, support multiple input methods, and adapt to appearance changes.

sections.title: Resources

subsections.title: Videos
subsections.summary: Three WWDC videos: 'Elevate the design of your iPad app', 'Meet Liquid Glass', 'Get to know the new design system'.

sections.summary: Collection of related resources including design assets, documentation pathways, and educational videos.

semanticStructure.documentFlow: The document begins with a hero section introducing iPadOS design, followed by a detailed breakdown of five device characteristics (Display, Ergonomics, Inputs, App interactions, System features). It then presents four best practices for iPad app design, and concludes with a resources section linking to design assets, documentation, and WWDC videos. The page uses a three-column layout with navigation sidebars and maintains consistent Apple Developer website styling throughout.

keyTerms.definition: Apple's operating system for iPad devices
Touch-based input method allowing multiple simultaneous touch points
Apple's stylus accessory for precise input on iPad
iPadOS feature allowing multiple apps to run and display simultaneously
iPadOS feature providing at-a-glance information from apps
Inter-app capability for moving content between applications
System-wide appearance setting using darker color palette
System feature allowing users to adjust text size
New design system/visual style introduced by Apple (referenced in WWDC video)

keyFindings: iPad users typically view the device from within 3 feet
People often combine multiple input modes when using iPad
Users appreciate viewing more than one app onscreen simultaneously
Apps should minimize modal interfaces and full-screen transitions
Apps should adapt seamlessly to device orientation, multitasking modes, Dark Mode, and Dynamic Type
iPad apps should transition effortlessly to running in macOS

designDecisions.rationale: Take advantage of large display to elevate content
Take advantage of large display to elevate content

designDecisions.decision: Position controls where easy to reach but not in the way
designDecisions.rationale: Optimize for iPad ergonomics and large display

designDecisions.decision: Consider viewing distance and input mode for content sizing
designDecisions.rationale: Users view iPad at varying distances and use different input methods

designDecisions.decision: Support multiple input modes including combinations
designDecisions.rationale: Users often combine Multi-Touch, keyboard, trackpad, and Apple Pencil
Users switch orientations, multitasking modes, Dark Mode, and Dynamic Type
Let users choose configurations that work best for them

mainContent.title: Designing for iPadOS
mainContent.subtitle: People value the power, mobility, and flexibility of iPad as they enjoy media, play games, perform detailed productivity tasks, and bring their creations to life.
mainContent.introSection: As you begin designing your app or game for iPad, start by understanding the following fundamental device characteristics and patterns that distinguish the iPadOS experience. Using these characteristics and patterns to inform your design decisions can help you provide an app or game that iPad users appreciate.
mainContent.displaySection: Display. iPad has a large, high-resolution display.
mainContent.ergonomicsSection: Ergonomics. People often hold their iPad while using it, but they might also set it on a surface or place it on a stand. Positioning the device in different ways can change the viewing distance, although people are typically within about 3 feet of the device as they interact with it.
mainContent.inputsSection: Inputs. People can interact with iPad using Multi-Touch gestures and virtual keyboards, an attached keyboard or pointing device, Apple Pencil, or voice, and they often combine multiple input modes.
mainContent.appInteractionsSection: App interactions. Sometimes, people perform a few quick actions on their iPad. At other times, they spend hours immersed in games, media, content creation, or productivity tasks. People frequently have multiple apps open at the same time, and they appreciate viewing more than one app onscreen at once and taking advantage of inter-app capabilities like drag and drop.
mainContent.systemFeaturesSection: System features. iPadOS provides several features that help people interact with the system and their apps in familiar, consistent ways.
mainContent.bestPracticesIntro: Great iPad experiences integrate the platform and device capabilities that people value most. To help your experience feel at home in iPadOS, prioritize the following ways to incorporate these features and capabilities.
bestPracticesList: Take advantage of the large display to elevate the content people care about, minimizing modal interfaces and full-screen transitions, and positioning onscreen controls where they're easy to reach, but not in the way.
Use viewing distance and input mode to help you determine the size and density of the onscreen content you display.
Let people use Multi-Touch gestures, a physical keyboard or trackpad, or Apple Pencil, and consider supporting unique interactions that combine multiple input modes.

Adapt seamlessly to appearance changes — like device orientation, multitasking modes, Dark Mode, and Dynamic Type — and transition effortlessly to running in macOS, letting people choose the configurations that work best for them.
